results.title: Projective generation of conics (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Introduces the eccentricity definition, then focuses on projective definitions devoid of metric notion implying the construction of a conic by straight edge alone. Shows methods of construction developed by Pascal, Malaurin, Braikenridge, Poncelet and Steiner. The logical relationship between the methods is demonstrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota

results.title: Regular homotopies in the plane. No. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Uses computer-generated animation in order to illustrate the Whitney-Graustein theorem - two regular curves in the plane are regularly homotopic if, and only if, they have the same rotation number.

results.title: Regular homotopies in the plane. No. 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Computer animation records the deformation of regular closed curves and the rotation of tangent vectors and demonstrates the theorem that two regular curves in the plane which are regularly homotopic must have the same rotation number. Concludes with a concrete problem and a challenge to explore the converse of the theorem as discussed in part 2.

results.title: Turning a sphere inside out (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard, David Nelson and Educational Development Center
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”
Uses advanced computer animation to discuss the problem of turning a sphere inside out by passing the surface through itself without making any holes or creases. Illustrates the homotopy with a sequence of models, showing the crucial stages in the motion.

results.title: Space filling curves (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard, Topology Films Project and Education Development Center
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Using computer animation the concept of a limit curve is graphically portrayed as a sequence of approximate curves and applied to the construction of space filling curves; curves which pass through every point in a square.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Hansard, Topology Films Project and Education Development Center

results.title: Central similarities (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Allen Downs, Jay Hines and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Dilatations (central similarities) are introduced to solve the problem of inscribing an ellipse to touch the sides of a given triangle at their midpoints. Coordinate geometry is also introduced to solve a subsidiary problem stressing the importance of the geometric interpretation of algebraic equations. Narrated by Delbert Ball.

results.title: Central perspectives (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Art Landy and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Reviews the definition of range and pencil. Introduces the basic projective transformation, namely the central perspectivity. When the narrator poses the question of the number of points required to uniquely determine a projectivity (product of perspectivity) the viewer is led to the fundamental theorem of projective geometry.

results.title: Geokids
results.creator_credit: Hank Saroyan, Caroline Somers, Bruce Somers Jnr and Lost Kitty Productions
results.brief_description: Created by Han Saroyan of the “Muppet babies”, this series features three amazingly life-like animal characters called Sunny, Bobby and Balzac. Small children are able to learn about many different types of animals and the way they behave.
